hints_html:
The area between a curve and the x-axis is just the integral from the function on the region.

Use the substitution u = 2x-4.
hints_latex:
The area between a curve and the \emph{x}-axis is just the integral from
the function on the region.
hints_raw:
The area between a curve and the ''x''-axis is just the integral from the function on the region.
Use the substitution ''u = 2x-4''.
question: 1 (g)
sols_html:
We proceed directly using the hints. First, the area is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{1}\frac{1}{(2x-4)^{2}}dx\end{aligned}\]

Using the substitution u = 2x-4 we find du = 2dx. When x = 0 we find u = -4, when x = 1 we find u = -2. Hence

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{1}\frac{1}{(2x-4)^{2}}dx &= \int_{-4}^{-2}\frac1{u^2} \frac{du}2\\ &= \frac12 \int_{-4}^{-2}u^{-2}du \\ &= \frac12 \left.(-u^{-1})\right|_{-4}^{-2} \\ &= -\frac12 ((-2)^{-1}-(-4)^{-1}) \\ &= -\frac12 \left(-\frac12 + \frac14\right)\\ &= \frac18\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We proceed directly using the hints. First, the area is given by

\begin{align*}
\int_{0}^{1}\frac{1}{(2x-4)^{2}}dx
\end{align*}

Using the substitution \emph{u = 2x-4} we find \emph{du = 2dx}. When
\emph{x = 0} we find \emph{u = -4}, when \emph{x = 1} we find \emph{u =
-2}. Hence

\begin{align*}
\int_{0}^{1}\frac{1}{(2x-4)^{2}}dx &= \int_{-4}^{-2}\frac1{u^2} \frac{du}2\\
&= \frac12 \int_{-4}^{-2}u^{-2}du \\
&= \frac12 \left.(-u^{-1})\right|_{-4}^{-2} \\
&= -\frac12 ((-2)^{-1}-(-4)^{-1}) \\
&= -\frac12 \left(-\frac12 + \frac14\right)\\
&= \frac18
\end{align*}
